text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Israeli newspapers on Thursday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
JERUSALEM POST
- U.S. envoy Dennis Ross to press Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on terror.
- Riots continue in territories.
- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu: No talks until Palestinian Authority combats terror.
- Ethiopian leaders lash Israeli army after third suicide in month.
- Chairman and general manager ask Bank Leumi's share committee to reconsider 600,000-shekel bonuses in wake of public outcry.
- Government to sign breakthrough procurement agreements with European Union.
- Annual earnings fall 68 percent at Clal Industries; Koor earnings up 8.4 percent last year.
- Trade Minister Natan Sharansky to meet Samsung delegation.
GLOBES
- Bezeq Communications directorate approves bonuses for workers from profits of sister companies -- despite opposition of Israeli companies authority.
HAARETZ
- United States demands Arafat prove an unequivocal commitment to the war against terrorism.
- In conversation with heads of rejectionist groups Arafat clearly was understood to express support for renewal of terror.
- Financial distress delays Labour party's preparations for local elections in 1998.
MAARIV
- Jonathan Pollard, American Jew jailed as spy for Israel, tells Maariv: "I was in shock when I understood that Israel had decided to condemn me".
- Record preparedness: Forces to be increased, leaves cancelled. Tanks not stationed in territories as yet, although armoured corps are close to expected trouble spots.
YEDIOTH AHRONOTH
- U.S. President Bill Clinton mobilises to save the peace process. Proposal at Jerusalem committee meeting in Morocco would freeze Arab states' relations with Israel.
- Average family overdraft in Israel runs to 5,300 shekels and half of all family shekel accounts are constantly overdrawn.
- Legal battle in Israel prevents screening of big Oscar winner "The English Patient".
